text: Welcome everyone. Today we are going to
begin something truly powerful.
Something that can change the way you
speak, think, and express yourself
forever.
Today, we start a complete journey, a
21-day plan to master English speaking
using seven powerful steps.
But we won't jump into all seven right
now. We'll take it one by one. and we'll
do it the right way with patience,
power, and full clarity. And this is not
going to be a boring grammar class. This
is not just tips and tricks. This is a
real transformation system. Because the
truth is, fluent English is not a
talent. Fluent English is a result, a
result of consistent speaking, brain
training, mouth training, and confidence
building. If you give your 100% for just
21 days and follow these steps honestly,
then I promise you, you will not just
learn to speak English. You will begin
to live inside English. You will stop
feeling nervous. You will speak without
fear. And you will look back and say, "I
did it. I broke the wall. I became the
speaker I always wanted to be." So,
let's begin this life-changing journey.
Let's go step by step. Step one, train
your mouth. Not just your brain. Days 1
to three. The most ignored step, but the
most powerful one. Most English learners
spend months or even years trying to
learn grammar, vocabulary, rules, books,
and exercises.
But they forget one thing. They forget
to train the tool that actually speaks.
And that tool is your mouth. You see
your brain may understand English. But
if your mouth is not trained to say the
words clearly, naturally, and
confidently, you will always hesitate.
You will always pause. You will always
feel nervous. You will always say, "I
know English, but I can't speak." That
is because your mouth is not ready. So
in this first step, our mission is
clear. We will train the muscles of your
mouth to speak English without fear,
without pausing, without feeling stuck.
Just like a singer trains their voice,
just like an athlete trains their body.
We will now train your mouth to speak
English fluently. When you speak in your
native language, your mouth is already
trained. You don't think, you just talk.
Your mouth knows how to form every word,
every sound, every sentence. But in
English, your tongue gets stuck. Your
lips feel tight. Your voice becomes
smaller. Your pronunciation becomes
unclear. And you hesitate. Why? Because
your mouth is not trained to make the
sounds of English. So in step one, we
will break that wall. We will speak
aloud every day. Not just think, not
just listen,
we will use our voice. One, the mirror
method. Your new daily ritual. Every
morning or evening, stand in front of
the mirror. Look directly into your own
eyes and speak out loud in English for 2
minutes. Yes, speak to yourself. Why?
Because when you look into your own eyes
and speak, you're not just practicing
words. You're practicing confidence.
You're teaching your mind. I can speak.
I will speak. I'm not afraid to speak.
What should you say? Anything. Keep it
simple. Example. Good morning. My name
is I am learning English. I love this
journey. I will speak English fluently.
I trust myself. I am growing. I am
improving. Do this for 2 minutes every
day. Don't try to be perfect. Just open
your mouth and speak. Two, daily
routine.
Speaking. Speak what you do. Your life
is the best practice topic. Talk about
your real day in English. Start with
simple sentences like, "I wake up at 7.
I brush my teeth. I drink water. I make
tea. I check my phone. I take a shower.
I wear my clothes. I go to work. I come
back home. I cook. I eat. I sleep. Say
these things aloud as you do them.
Repeat the same sentence two to three
times clearly. If you do this every day,
your mouth will learn to speak English
automatically, just like your native
language. Three, speak each sentence 10
times. Mouth muscle repetition. Pick
three short sentences every day and
repeat them out loud 10 times each. The
more you say a sentence, the more
comfortable your mouth becomes. Here are
some examples. English is easy. I am
improving every day. I will speak
fluently. Repeat each one 10 times
slowly and clearly. Don't just whisper.
Don't just say it in your mind. Use your
full voice. This is like exercise. You
are building muscle memory. Four, record
your voice. Track your progress. Use
your phone. Record one minute of
yourself speaking every day. Just say
what you did today. Example, today I
woke up at 700 a.m. I brushed my teeth.
I made tea. I listened to an English
video. I went for a walk. I talked to
myself in English. I am practicing
daily. Then listen to your recording.
Even if you don't like your voice,
listen. This is how you become aware of
your improvement. You will hear your
progress. You will notice the change and
that will motivate you. Don't try to be
perfect. Just speak. Don't worry about
grammar. Don't use your native language
at all while practicing. Don't pause.
Even if you make mistakes,
don't quit. These three days will change
your comfort level forever. Step two,
think in English all day, all night, day
four to day six. Train your brain to
live inside English, not outside it. Let
me tell you something most learners
never hear. You can't speak English
fluently if you're still thinking in
your native language. That's the silent
block. That's the hidden wall. You may
know grammar. You may know vocabulary.
You may even speak a few sentences.
But if your brain is still thinking in
another language and translating every
word before you speak, then you will
always be slow. You will always pause.
You will always hesitate. You will
always feel nervous. And that's why this
step, think in English, is not optional.
It's not a trick. It's a requirement for
fluency. This is the step where your
English becomes automatic.
This is where your brain says, "I no
longer need translation. I live in
English now." And when that happens,
speaking becomes natural. You don't
think how to speak. You just speak. So
now we train the most powerful tool of
all, your mind. You might ask, "What
does it really mean to think in
English?"
It means when you wake up your first
thought is in English. When you see your
phone your brain says check messages.
When you feel hungry your brain says I
want to eat something. Not your native
language thought translate to English
speak. That's slow. That's painful. You
want your mind to think directly in
English without translation. This is
fluency. This is power. This is freedom.
You will follow these five systems every
single day. These are not tips. These
are not tricks. These are mindrewiring
tools that force your brain to enter
English mode and stay there. One, name
everything around you in English. 5
minutes per hour. This is your new
habit. Every 1 to two hours during the
day, stop for a moment and look at your
surroundings. Say the names of the
things you see. Say it softly or in your
mind. Like, this is my phone. That is a
black chair. This is a window. It is
open. The fan is on. I see a book. The
cover is red. Why do we do this? Because
your brain needs repetition.
When you name real things in real time,
in real situations,
you build a connection between your life
and English.
That connection is stronger than any
grammar rule. And the more you do this,
the more English becomes your natural
environment.
Two, narrate your life like a story. 5
to 10 minutes three times a day. This is
a secret method used by many fluency
coaches. You will speak your life as it
is happening. You don't need to create
fake examples. You don't need complex
vocabulary.
Just describe what is happening to you
like a commentator. Start with this
simple format. Right now I am sitting. I
am using my phone. I am reading this
guide. I am learning English. I want to
become fluent. Later add more detail.
Now I'm thinking about my goals. I want
to travel one day. I imagine myself
speaking English in another country. I
feel proud of myself. I am trying hard.
I will never quit. You don't need
perfect grammar. You don't need big
words. You just need to think out loud
in simple English. This will completely
reprogram your brain. Three, write five
thoughts in English every night. Don't
skip this. Before sleeping, take 10
minutes. Write five real thoughts from
your mind in English. This is not
schoolwork. This is not homework. This
is brain training. Like I felt tired
today. I worked hard. I didn't speak
perfectly but I tried. I want to improve
more. Tomorrow I will speak more
confidently.
Now here's the trick. After writing
them, say them aloud three times. So
your brain not only thinks them, your
mouth says them. Your ears hear them.
Your entire system begins to believe
them. And the more real the thought, the
stronger the result.
Four, English thoughts. During silent
time, morning toilet, travel, walking.
You don't need extra time to think in
English. Use your silent moments. You
know those quiet minutes when you're
brushing your teeth, taking a shower,
walking alone, sitting in a bus, waiting
in line, eating alone before sleep. Use
those exact moments to say, "What am I
doing right now? What am I feeling? What
will I do next? I am brushing my teeth.
My mouth feels fresh. The water is cold.
I am walking to the market. I see cars.
I feel the air. I like this moment."
These are real, simple, powerful
thoughts. Your brain is building speed
plus structure plus vocabulary from real
life. Do this every day. Never skip.
Five, don't translate. Block your native
language on purpose. This is very
important. From day four to day six, you
must try your best to avoid translation.
If you don't know a word, skip it or
explain it in English. If you don't know
the word spoon, just say, "This is a
small thing. I eat with it. It is
metal." That's called thinking in
English.
You didn't stop. You didn't translate.
You explained it in English. This is
what fluent speakers do. They don't
pause. They don't freeze. They move
forward even with simple words. You must
teach your brain to survive and speak
without needing translation. That is
true fluency. If you want to go even
deeper, try these. Talk to yourself
silently in English before you sleep.
Close your eyes. Ask yourself, "How was
my day?" Answer in English in your mind.
Change phone language to English. Make
your brain see English everywhere. Force
your system to learn the words
naturally. Set English alarms with
affirmations.
Alarm label. I speak English. I believe
in myself. When it rings, say that
aloud. Build daily identity. Step three.
The pen or pencil trick. Day seven to
day nine.
You can know English. You can think in
English. You can even understand English
movies, podcasts, and videos. But if
your mouth is not trained to move
clearly, freely and fast, then your
words will still come out slow, unclear,
and weak. Speaking English requires
physical movement. Your mouth is a
muscle. Your tongue, your jaw, your
lips, all of them must move in a new way
when you speak English. And if they are
not trained, your pronunciation will
always be weak. You will always feel
like your voice is not clear. People may
say, "Can you repeat that?" And you may
feel shy, nervous, or quiet again. But
don't worry, there's a powerful trick
that actors, singers, speakers, and
English learners around the world have
used for years. It's simple. It's
strange, and it works like magic. It's
called the pen or pencil trick. You take
a pen or pencil, not too thick. Place it
horizontally between your teeth, gently.
Your mouth is now slightly open. You
speak English sentences aloud with the
pen or pencil in your mouth. At first,
it will feel difficult. Your mouth will
feel stretched. Your words will feel
unclear.
You may even laugh. But that's the whole
point. Because what's happening is this.
Your jaw muscles are opening more. Your
tongue becomes stronger and more active.
Your lip movement improves. Your mouth
learns to pronounce every word clearly.
even in a difficult position. And then
after 2 minutes, you remove the pen and
say the same sentences again. You will
immediately notice something amazing.
Your mouth feels lighter. Your voice
becomes sharper. Your sentences become
clearer. You feel like you're in control
of your words. That's because you just
trained your mouth like a gym. You
pushed your muscles. And now English
flows more easily. This is not magic.
This is muscle memory. And this trick
helps you build it fast. Most people
speak English using only 20 to 30% of
their mouth movement capacity. Their jaw
stays tight. Their lips barely move.
Their tongue doesn't stretch enough. But
the sounds of English require full
movement. Especially vowels, clarity,
and connected speech. By putting a pen
in your mouth, you force your jaw to
open wider. You force your tongue to
move more powerfully.
You force your lips to try harder. It's
like running with weights on your legs.
It's hard at first, but when you remove
the weights, you run faster. The same
thing happens here. You practice
speaking in a more difficult condition.
And when you return to normal speaking,
you feel more clear, relaxed, powerful.
This is why actors in training programs
do this regularly.
They become masters of pronunciation
because they train their mouths like an
athlete trains muscles. One, choose
three sentences per day. Pick three
simple but useful sentences every day.
Start with short and clear lines. Here
are some examples you can use. I am
learning English every day. I believe in
myself. I can speak clearly and
confidently.
This is the best time to grow. I will
never give up on speaking. You can also
use your own lines based on your day.
Now you're ready. Place the pen in your
mouth horizontally.
Take a clean pen or pencil. Place it
gently between your teeth horizontally
like you're biting it gently. Do not
push too hard. Keep it safe.
Now try to say your three sentences with
the pen still in your mouth. You will
feel it is difficult. Your words will
not be clear. That's okay. Speak slowly
with effort. Say each sentence five
times with the pen. Focus on trying to
pronounce every sound clearly, even if
it's hard.
This is how you stretch your speaking
ability. Remove the pen and speak again.
Feel the power. After you finish five
rounds per sentence, remove the pen.
Take a deep breath. Now speak the same
sentences again normally. This time you
will notice a huge difference. Your
words are easier. Your pronunciation is
clearer. Your jaw feels more open. Your
voice has more strength. You just
trained like a fluency athlete. This is
powerful practice. Mirror speaking after
pen practice. Now go to the mirror. Look
at yourself and say all three sentences
again with full confidence. Feel your
mouth move. Feel your voice become
strong. Feel the English flowing from
you. Not from fear but from power. Say
my voice is strong. My English is clear.
I can speak. I will speak. I'm already
doing it. Don't bite too hard. Keep the
pen gently between your teeth. Don't try
to speak fast. Speak slowly and clearly.
Don't worry about sounding funny. That's
part of the training. Don't skip this.
These three days will rewire your mouth
and brain together. Don't stop if it
feels hard. That means it's working.
Want to improve even faster? While you
speak with the pen, stand in front of
the mirror. Look at your mouth. Look at
your face. Watch your muscles try hard.
This makes your brain pay more attention
and that improves your results. Step
four, build your confidence muscle. Day
10 to day 12. What is confidence in
English speaking? Confidence is not the
absence of mistakes. Confidence is not
speaking fast. Confidence is not having
a British or American accent. Confidence
is this. You speak anyway, even if you
make mistakes.
You speak even if people are watching.
You speak even when your heart is
beating fast. You speak even if your
grammar is not 100%.
You speak because you know this is how I
grow.
Confidence is not given. Confidence is
built like a muscle. So, let's build it
now. You're going to build confidence
through five daily actions. Each one is
designed to challenge your comfort zone
and expand your speaking power. Step by
step. Affirmation speaking. Reprogram
your belief system. Every morning and
night, stand in front of a mirror. Look
at yourself and say these sentences out
loud, slowly and with full belief.
Repeat each sentence three times. I am
not afraid to speak English. My English
is improving every day. I believe in my
voice. I will not stop. I will not quit.
I will speak. Mistakes do not stop me.
They make me stronger. This is mental
reprogramming. You're not just saying
words. You are installing belief into
your nervous system. You must speak them
like you mean them with full power and
volume. Look into your own eyes and say,
"I am not afraid anymore."
Speak 5 minutes about yourself. Every
day, no script, no preparation. Just set
a timer and talk about anything related
to your life. Your childhood, your
family, your daily routine, your dreams,
your favorite food, what you learned
today. Talk like you are speaking to a
friend. Why this works? You know the
topic. It's your life. You don't need
big vocabulary. You stop worrying about
perfection. You learn to enjoy speaking.
Even if you get stuck, keep going. Even
if you repeat the same thing, keep
going. Even if you feel nervous, keep
going. Because confidence is built
through repetition, not perfection. Do
one brave English action daily.
Confidence comes from action, not
thinking. You must challenge yourself in
small ways every day. Choose one of
these actions per day. Leave a voice
note in English to a friend. Record a
video message to your future self in
English.
Speak English in public for 30 seconds,
even softly.
Ask a small question in English on
social media or an app. Talk to a family
member in English for one minute. Use
only English for 10 minutes in your
home. It may feel scary, but that's the
point. Every time you take a brave
action, you gain one point of
confidence. And these points compound
like money. Visualize yourself speaking
English fluently. Sit quietly. Close
your eyes. Imagine this clearly. You are
standing in a room. You are speaking
fluent English. People are listening.
You are not afraid. You are smiling. You
are expressing your ideas with clarity
and strength. You are free. You are
fluent. You are powerful. Do this for 2
minutes every morning and every night
because your brain doesn't know the
difference between imagination and real
experience.
So the more you visualize yourself as
confident, the faster you become that
person.
Celebrate your progress daily, no matter
how small. At the end of each day, ask
yourself, what did I speak today? What
did I try? What did I learn? What did I
feel scared of but still did anyway?
Write the answers or say them out loud.
Then say, "I'm proud of myself. I did
something that 90% of people are afraid
to do. I showed up. I spoke. I'm
growing."
Confidence doesn't come from big
results. It comes from showing up every
day. Even when you're scared, you don't
wait for confidence. You build it. Step
five, speak through stories. Day 13 to
day 15. When a child learns a language,
do they learn grammar rules first? Do
they memorize vocabulary lists first? Do
they study tenses, rules, exceptions?
No, they don't. They learn through
stories. They listen to stories. They
tell stories. They repeat stories. And
this simple truth still applies to you
because the moment you start using your
life, your past, your imagination, and
your feelings as spoken stories, you
move one step closer to natural,
effortless fluency.
Here's what most learners get wrong.
They focus too much on rules. They focus
too much on remembering the right
sentence. But when you tell a story, you
stop focusing on being perfect and you
start focusing on being real. That's
when your fluency grows faster than
ever. Because speaking a story activates
everything at the same time. Your brain,
your memory, your emotions, your
vocabulary, your past tense usage, your
sentence building skills, your
confidence.
In short, stories are the shortcut to
fluency. Now, let's go deep into how to
practice it in the most powerful,
enjoyable, and effective way possible.
It means that instead of learning
English by topic, like verbs or sports
or jobs, you learn by speaking stories
about your real life, you take any
moment from your day or your past
and you describe it like a simple story.
You say what happened. You say what you
saw. You say what you felt. You don't
worry about perfect English. You speak
like a human being telling a memory. And
that's when your English starts sounding
natural and fluent. You are no longer a
student. You are now a storyteller. And
storytellers connect. Storytellers speak
with emotion. Storytellers speak with
confidence. Storytellers speak in a way
that people want to listen. You don't
need advanced grammar. You just need
your voice, your memory, and your heart.
What kind of stories should you tell?
Simple ones. Real ones. Stories that
live inside you. Examples: A funny thing
that happened last week. Your childhood
memory. A time you were very happy. A
day you will never forget. A small fight
you had with someone. Your first job or
your first school, the first time you
traveled somewhere, a mistake you made
and what you learned, something your
mother or father said that you still
remember.
A recent day, what you did from morning
to night. Each of these topics can
become a five-inut spoken story.
And each time you tell it, you speak
better, faster, and with more emotion.
And here's the best part. The story
never changes,
but your English improves every time you
tell it again. Step six, listening. The
secret weapon, day 16 to day 18.
If you want to speak clearly, naturally,
and confidently in English, you must
first listen clearly, naturally, and
actively because your brain is like a
machine. It learns by hearing patterns.
When you hear something again and again,
your brain remembers it, your brain
copies it, your brain uses it, and
eventually you speak it without even
thinking. That's how babies learn.
That's how you learned your first
language. That's how you can learn to
speak English like a fluent person. Not
by memorizing rules, but by listening to
real English every single day. Here's
what happens to most English learners.
They try to speak, but they don't listen
enough. So, they don't hear real English
sounds, words, tone, flow. So when they
speak it sounds broken, slow, robotic or
confusing. Why? Because their mouth is
not copying anything real. Their brain
doesn't recognize the music of English.
But when you listen daily, even for 10
minutes, your brain starts to wake up.
It starts recognizing sounds, tone,
speed, emotion, and sentence flow. And
it begins to say, "Ah, this is how they
say it. Now I understand the rhythm. Now
I know where to pause. Now I know how to
say it like them.
That's what listening gives you. It
gives you the natural structure of the
language. Not from grammar books but
from real voices. And when you add
shadowing, copying the speaker, it
becomes even more powerful.
Let me show you exactly how to do it.
This is not just watch English movies.
This is intentional listening where you
train your ears like a musician. You
listen, you focus, you copy, you repeat
and slowly your brain gets used to
English speed, tone, accent, structure,
and rhythm. It's like learning a song.
At first, you don't understand every
word, but when you hear it every day,
you start to know the lyrics. You start
to sing along. You start to feel the
flow. That's how listening makes you a
speaker. This step is divided into two
core activities.
Focused listening, shadowing, copying
the speaker word for word. You will do
both every day for 3 days. Even if
you're busy, give it just 20 minutes per
day. That 20 minutes will change your
English forever. Focused listening 10
minutes daily. Choose a short audio or
video 1 to 3 minutes long. It can be a
YouTube video by a native speaker, a
podcast for beginners, a short speech, a
real life story in English, a movie
scene with clear speech. Important. The
English should be real, clear, and slow
or medium paced. Now follow these steps.
Step A. Listen once without subtitles.
Just listen. Don't worry if you don't
understand everything. Focus on the
tone, speed, emotion, and feeling. Step
B. Listen again now with subtitles. Read
and listen together. Notice how the
speaker joins words. Notice how some
words are fast, some slow. See where the
pauses come. Step C. Listen a third
time. Close your eyes.
Try to imagine the meaning.
Let your brain understand the English
like music. Do this with just one video
per day. You don't need five different
videos. You need one video repeated
three times with focus. This is how your
ears get trained. Shadowing 10 minutes
daily. Shadowing means you listen to a
sentence and immediately repeat it out
loud, copying the speaker's voice as
closely as possible.
This trains mouth movement,
pronunciation,
accent, rhythm, sentence structure. This
is what actors and public speakers do
when they learn a new language. Play one
short sentence from your video or audio.
Pause. Repeat the same sentence out loud
exactly like the speaker. Try to copy
speed, energy, tone, pronunciation. Do
this for the full one to two minute
audio. Repeat the full audio two or
three times in your voice. You are not
just repeating. You are absorbing
fluency from the voice you hear. Your
mouth learns new movements. Your brain
learns new patterns. Your English
becomes real. What if you don't
understand every word? That's okay. You
are not listening to understand every
word. You are listening to feel the
sound, structure and rhythm of real
English and slowly your understanding
will increase and then your speaking
will become more natural. Don't pause
after every mistake. Don't feel bad if
you miss something. Just keep going.
Fluency is not built in silence. Fluency
is built in constant repetitive
listening. Step seven, practice real
conversations.
Day 19 to day 21.
You can train your brain. You can train
your mouth. You can build confidence.
You can think in English. You can shadow

Use English in real time conversation.
